quotation: One of the key risks to the U.S. and global economic recovery is the sovereign debt crisis in Europe... In order for the sovereign debt crisis to derail the global recovery, it would have to morph into a global uncertainty shock on the order of the Lehman-AIG episode during the fall of 2008.
description: European sovereign debt crisis poses risks but unlikely to cause major global financial shock

quotation: But it's fairly clear that we're beginning to see a disinflationary process going on, starting largely from the balance sheet structure of businesses as well as the financial system. And I think that's a major element that is feeding into the basic price structure.
description: Disinflationary process originating from balance sheet problems

quotation: You could have had the initial view—which was kind of my view—that we're in the Rogoff– Reinhart world, in which it was a financial-crisis-induced recession with a big change in asset values, resulting in a lot of debt work-off.
description: Current economic conditions reflect financial-crisis-induced recession with ongoing debt work-off process

quotation: Moreover, in general, inflation has many determinants. We've talked a lot about the effects of well-anchored inflation expectations, but in the last few years we've also seen some very big swings in commodity prices, which in turn are influenced by global conditions.
description: Inflation has many determinants beyond economic slack, including well-anchored expectations and commodity prices

quotation: If the procedure has had a defect, in my mind it has been the excessive volatility of interest rates. Given the biases that I have, I've been more concerned about the rapid decline [in rates] in the second quarter of last year than about the way they got up to 20 percent on two occasions. And now that I hear from Mr. Axilrod that apparently the sharp drop in the second quarter didn't have much of an economic repercussion--that the quick revival of the economy was largely the work of the real sector and perhaps the credit control removal, not the drop in interest rates as I had thought--
description: FOMC member expresses concern about excessive volatility in credit markets and acknowledges that credit control removal was more important than interest rate changes in driving economic recovery

quotation: Despite very prolonged and substantial headwinds in the context of an oil shock, a large ongoing drag from net exports, a significant tightening of financial conditions, a modest withdrawal of fiscal stimulus, etc., quarterly GDP growth—as Janet said— has shown impressive stability around a 3½ percent annual rate over the last year and a half.
description: Recent GDP growth has demonstrated impressive stability and resilience despite significant economic headwinds

quotation: The financial markets have really provided wind at the back of the broader economy throughout this most recent period, even until a month ago. I think the open question, and the hardest, is whether those financial markets will prove sufficiently resilient—that is, whether the underlying shocks to the economy that might occur are exacerbated by this financial market situation or whether the worst of the outcomes are made less severe by the financial markets.
description: Financial markets face uncertain resilience and could either exacerbate or mitigate economic shocks

quotation: At the present time commodity prices, although they have the reputation of being very volatile, seem rather stable to me. If there's any trend it's probably slightly upward but not as strong as ordinarily would be seen in a recovery phase. So, on the surface that doesn't seem to show great inflation signals out ahead.
description: Current commodity prices do not show strong inflation signals ahead

quotation: We are at a point, as Simon pointed out—and by the way, excellent presentation—where we have had this enormous rally, a lot of issuance. Interestingly, yesterday with Brown-Forman's issue of that one bond—they are the purveyors of Jack Daniel's whiskey, which is why I paid attention to it—we did break through the record at $1.025 trillion in investment-grade credits.
description: Credit markets experiencing record issuance and enormous rally

quotation: The feedback loop between the financial markets and the real economy just intensified—turned up many, many notches at that time.
description: Negative feedback loop between financial markets and real economy is intensifying the downturn

quotation: In fact, we see businesses restructuring--not restructuring in the '80s style of piling on a lot of debt but rather restructuring in terms of selling assets to pay down debt, cutting expenses, laying off people, and shutting down plants. And that's not exactly the kind of environment in which one expects an immediate return of a high level of business activity.
description: Business restructuring environment delays recovery expectations

quotation: lower energy prices do help cushion the effects of the housing slowdown, and they do reduce the downside risk to growth over the near term.
description: Energy price decline reduces downside risks to growth

quotation: The improved tenor of the incoming data has been clearly reflected in the comments coming from business contacts in the Sixth District in this intermeeting cycle. The best characterization of those comments is more optimistic than before the December meeting but still a bit tentative, cautious, and reluctant to place significant bets on stronger demand.
description: Business sentiment is improving but remains cautious and reluctant to bet on stronger demand

quotation: Nevertheless, as I assess the economic environment this morning relative to where I was in January, particularly given the prospects of yet larger wealth losses stemming from the real estate market and certainly the chance for even greater impairment to the functioning of our credit markets, I think the downside risks to economic growth continue to outweigh the upside risks to inflation.
description: Speaker judges that downside risks to economic growth outweigh upside risks to inflation

quotation: He concludes that if, as seems likely, activity falls enough in coming months for the NBER to declare a recession, the business cycle peak could well be backdated to the first half of this year and perhaps as early as March.
description: Economic activity likely to fall enough for NBER to declare recession with peak possibly in March

quotation: There was recently a strike of operating engineers in connection with which 20,000 of 30,000 construction workers in the St. Louis area went out. That strike was settled in about two weeks with total compensation increases of about 2 to 3 percent in salary and benefits.
description: Construction worker strike resolved with modest wage increases

quotation: And what bothers me about the financial system is not only the direct impact on lending but also that the bad news about banks feeds directly into consumer confidence it seems to me. And then there's also the low probability but serious outcome of a crack in the financial system.
description: Banking problems have direct negative effects on lending and broader consumer confidence, creating systemic risks

quotation: There is clearly no risk-free course for us here; there are risks on both sides. The idea that we can absolutely thread the needle between the risks is probably a nice hope but it may be an illusion.
description: No risk-free policy course exists given competing economic risks

quotation: The household debt overhang could weigh on consumers for some time, as in the weaker consumption alternative scenario reported in the Greenbook. And in that scenario, the unemployment rate doesn't fall below 9 percent until 2012.
description: In downside scenario with household debt overhang, unemployment recovery could be even slower, not falling below 9 percent until 2012

quotation: So, while I've been of the view that the financial market improvements over the last year have been helping the real side of the economy, I suspect that they will no longer be as convincingly useful to get the real economy to go forward.
description: Financial market improvements will no longer be as supportive of real economic growth

quotation: I guess I wouldn't necessarily associate it with, say, the development of the secondary market or the ease of equity extraction, and those sorts of things, but I'm not saying they're irrelevant.
description: Secondary market development and equity extraction ease are not necessarily major drivers of housing price dynamics

quotation: The ripple effects on investors and on the confidence factors in the economy I think are kind of awesome to contemplate, plus the fact that we are just digging the hole for the thrifts at a much greater and faster rate with this, and nobody has yet come up with the right answer to that one.
description: Concern about ripple effects on investors and worsening problems for thrift institutions with rate increases

quotation: I think the real vulnerability is the financial system; I just don't know what will be the specific trigger to ring the bell there. I don't know whether it will be in farm credit, whether it will be some fallout from what is now going on in Maryland, or whether it will be something more in the mortgage-backed securities area, but my stomach tells me that [the financial system] will be the trigger that will cause the unwinding.
description: Financial system vulnerabilities in credit markets pose risks to economic stability

quotation: One can't help but think that what happens—it's like the old redlining issue—is that first some foreclosures occur on a block, and pretty soon the values of the homes start going down, and then a lot of people stop making mortgage payments. I don't think that has macro significance, but it is a big problem in certain neighborhoods.
description: Localized foreclosure clusters create causal chains of declining home values and increased mortgage defaults, but lack macro significance

quotation: The very high levels of debt of both businesses and consumers are a further deterrent, particularly if people are concerned about unemployment and the possibility of being laid off.
description: High debt levels of businesses and consumers are deterring economic activity

quotation: Last time and today, Dave Stockton cited several downside risks to watch for: an intensified fallout from the problems in mortgage finance onto housing demand; a substantial drop in consumer sentiment; and a spillover from financial market disruptions to business spending.
description: Financial market disruptions pose spillover risks to business spending

quotation: The recent sharp deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook and the forced deleveraging of the nonbank portion of the financial sector have led to sharp declines in asset values during the past few months.
description: Recent sharp deterioration in macroeconomic outlook driven by deleveraging and asset price declines

quotation: I do, though, expect a resumption of moderate growth. I think it's a testament to this economy that, given the amount of leverage we are trying to work our way through, we have seen economic growth at 2½ to 3 percent.
description: Despite deleveraging headwinds, the economy has demonstrated resilience with 2.5-3% growth and moderate growth resumption is expected

quotation: So, if we do have a slow economy right now, I think we ought to ask ourselves if it is because we've followed an inappropriately tight money policy. And it seems to me that the answer to that is fairly clearly "no." There is plenty of liquidity in the system... it just seems pretty obvious to me that the sluggishness we're dealing with does not have its origin in overly tight monetary policy.
description: Current economic sluggishness does not originate from overly tight monetary policy

quotation: I'm more worried about the business fixed investment, and I say that because, anecdotally, survey work—there's no large firm in America, I believe, that's saying, 'We're not investing because of the cost of capital.' Now, there may be an issue about deductibility and related matters, right, and the expensing of capital, and it may be that small and medium-sized enterprises have some constraint. But I don't hear anybody right now saying they're not investing because capital is too expensive.
description: Current credit market conditions (cost of capital) are not constraining business investment for large firms

quotation: The reduction in credit supply originating in small and medium-sized institutions was a large part of the headwinds in monetary policy that Chairman Greenspan highlighted during that period.
description: Historical precedent of credit supply disruption from small/medium banks causing macroeconomic consequences

quotation: I think the world economy is literally starved for liquidity. And I'd liken this [situation] to the dietary analogy that suggests. Fat people have good reasons to go on diets. Diets are very good things unless they get out of hand. They sometimes do. And when they get out of hand, the patient becomes anorexic and that's often a fatal disease. If it's not fatal, it's often a life-long disease. I am worried that we have gone on long enough starving the world economy for liquidity and that we may be at a point of impending anorexia.
description: The world economy is starved for liquidity and risks economic anorexia from continued tight policy

quotation: The one tangible number that I can recite to you is out of a survey of farm land prices; they have decreased another 2-1/2 percent in the second quarter of 1984. That has an impact, obviously, that rolls back into the financial system that we quite likely will see around the first quarter of 1985.
description: Farm land price declines will negatively impact the financial system, with effects expected in early 1985

quotation: Currently, there is a risk of some cumulative difficulty, complicated not just by normal kinds of cumulative difficulties in recessions but by financial problems that we can't see very clearly but may be there. We have an uneasy feeling they may be there.
description: There are risks of cumulative financial difficulties that are not clearly visible but may be present

quotation: Unemployment rates are about flat; they edged up very slightly in the most recent month.
description: Unemployment rates remain flat with slight recent increase

quotation: The development of a much wider array of financing vehicles for both borrowers and lenders-- and in particular the capacity of the capital markets to securitize and sell vast quantities of mortgages--may well allow the overall level of economic activity to escape being significantly affected by the rechannelling of savings flows.
description: Financial market innovations may insulate economic activity from savings flow disruptions

quotation: It seems clear to me in talking with people in that industry that lower interest rates are not a solution to the agricultural problem. That is, without an increase in commodity prices we're going to see the situation continue to deteriorate... So, we could drop that rate 3 or 4 percentage points and on the margin it would help certain farmers and ranchers. But by and large it has to be an increase in commodity prices in the period ahead that will salvage this situation; interest rates are not the key to it.
description: Lower interest rates would not solve agricultural credit problems because commodity prices, not interest rates, are the key factor

quotation: The second reason is that we do not observe any telltale signs, such as overexpansion by one or more industries or fragile household balance sheets, that would suggest that some repricing of risky assets and perhaps some restraint in credit creation would trigger significant changes in real economic behavior of firms or households.
description: Limited signs of credit stress abroad suggest repricing of risky assets and credit restraint may not significantly impact real economic behavior internationally

quotation: On the inflation front, some reports suggest increasing industrial goods price pressure. This is what we hear from our board, and this is what businesses are reporting in their comments to us around the District.
description: Regional reports indicate increasing industrial goods price pressure

quotation: In my mind, there are three key determinants of the outlook over the next few quarters. The first one is Europe, and we saw earlier how powerful the contagion was back to the U.S., especially in terms of those financial intermediaries, like Morgan Stanley, that have very limited access to the Fed's lender-of-last resort function. If Europe goes badly, then there is a real risk to the U.S. financial system; and then, by extension, to financial conditions; and then to the real economy.
description: European risks pose significant threat to U.S. growth through financial contagion

quotation: Because the trajectory of house prices will depend in part on financial behavior—the availability of credit—as financial institutions catch up and adjust to that and adjust capital and asset growth, et cetera, there is some risk that you'll push that expected path of house prices down further from where it is.
description: Credit availability causally affects house prices through financial institution behavior

quotation: In view of the recent weakness in the economic data and the downgrading of the forecast, I would favor modifying the final sentence in our statement to indicate that we intend to fulfill our obligations to promote both price stability and sustainable growth.
description: Policy should emphasize both price stability and sustainable growth mandates

quotation: Both historical experience and economic research point to the risk that excesses in corporate debt markets could amplify any adverse shocks to the economy. Overindebted businesses may face payment strains when earnings fall unexpectedly, and they typically respond by pulling back disproportionately on both investment and employment, and that kind of behavior then amplifies volatility by reducing investors' demand for risky assets.
description: Corporate debt excesses could amplify adverse economic shocks through investment and employment cuts

quotation: What we're seeing at this stage is a far slower [than usual process of adjustment], where in effect the contraction follows the very heavy and excessive debt creation of the 1986-87 period, the subsequent gradual retrenchment of debt growth and M2 growth, and basically, deleveraging beginning to occur, arriving at a point where I gather we had record equity issuance in April.
description: Economy is undergoing deleveraging following excessive debt creation in 1986-87 period

quotation: Up to now, the consequences of the crisis on U.S. economic activity appear to have been quite muted. Although European banks are actively deleveraging, there is little evidence that this is significantly constraining credit in the United States.
description: European crisis has not significantly constrained U.S. credit availability despite bank deleveraging

quotation: I think it is useful to formally make price stability the primary objective over the long run. The proper way to look at it from my point of view is that price stability is a means to an end, not an end in itself. The ultimate end of all economic policy is higher standards of living and growth and that sort of thing.
description: Price stability should be the primary long-term monetary policy objective as it leads to higher living standards and growth

quotation: And I might say that the continual increase of land prices is [supporting the use of land as] collateral for the additional extension of credit, not only by the banks but PCAs. If something were to occur, such as a mass selling out of farmers, for example- -that might affect those prices on the downside. You may find the farm loans without sufficient collateral even if they chose to foreclose, because the increase in farm land prices is what's supporting these additional extensions of credit.
description: Rising land prices support credit extension but create vulnerability if prices decline

quotation: I think there is a non-negligible risk that the constrictions in credit availability would feed back on the economy and, in turn, feed back on credit supply.
description: Risk of negative feedback loops between credit availability and economic activity

quotation: I asked a simple question: If the actions we were to take at this upcoming meeting were to reduce your cost of capital by 25 basis points or more, what would it do in terms of your investment plans? I deliberately sampled larger companies because that's where cap-ex comes from. And I would say that 9 out of 10 said it would not change their investment plans, even if we took action that led to a reduction of 1 percent or more in their cost of capital.
description: Large corporations will not increase investment even with significant reductions in cost of capital

quotation: I suspect that this is a long, slow climb with the credit channels needing to be rebuilt and that the process is still in its very early stages.
description: Credit channels require long-term structural rebuilding process that is in early stages

quotation: I think that if you assume any kind of wealth effect coming from an "I-am-scared-to-death" 20 percent correction in stock prices, especially if the latter were to occur relatively quickly, the flow of funds would be from the stock market into the bond market and instead of the long-term interest rates going up as in the forecast, I think one might expect them to come down.
description: Stock market corrections lead to flight-to-quality flows that cause long-term interest rates to fall rather than rise

quotation: I recognize that some downside risks remain, including some potentially large and negative shocks, but I do not think we should exacerbate our long-term problem with still lower interest rates unless the downside risks loom larger or the negative shocks are realized.
description: Should not exacerbate long-term problems with lower rates unless risks materialize

quotation: And reactions in those markets are reinforcing the caution in business and household spending, in part by offsetting the effects of policy easing on financial conditions.
description: Financial market reactions are reinforcing caution and offsetting the effects of policy easing on financial conditions

quotation: The rationing of credit for real estate development in markets that had become a bit frothy should help damp the boom/bust cycles that we have seen so many times in that industry.
description: Credit rationing in frothy real estate markets will help dampen boom/bust cycles

quotation: On the other hand, our District business contacts suggest they will continue to invest in equipment that can mitigate the effects of ongoing labor shortages and also to accommodate high sales volumes, even as capital costs have increased modestly.
description: Labor shortages are driving business investment in labor-saving equipment

quotation: I must say, as a side note to this, that in a meeting in Basle earlier this month, a number of my fellow central bankers discussed with me their view that money does not disappear. I disagreed. When markets delever, money goes away and credit comes in. In the macro sense, one can look at the Japanese money supply; money really is disappearing in Japan. In a shorter-run sense, if the parties financing counterparties take away the financing, borrower balance sheets shrink and in one sense money is disappearing.
description: Deleveraging causes money and credit to disappear, creating deflationary pressures

quotation: the longer there are no obvious spinoffs from the subprime problem to the wider economy, the more that particular risk seems to ebb
description: Subprime mortgage risks to the broader economy are diminishing over time

quotation: And as that kind of conversation wafts its way through suburbia, not to mention exurbia, the tendency is to build up those good old precautionary balances and to have a liquidity preference that is a bit different from what it was when one could go and get $15,000 or $25,000 on the residential mortgage.
description: Reduced credit availability is causing consumers to increase precautionary balances and change liquidity preferences

quotation: Cold, snowy gales have held back growth. Pinning down the effects of adverse weather on economic activity is always difficult, even well after the fact, but it appears a good share of the recent economic slowdown reflects unseasonable cold and snow.
description: Recent economic slowdown largely reflects temporary weather effects

quotation: Concern that the level of real rates, tightening credit conditions, and fragile financial conditions could undermine the expansion might argue for a downward tilt in the directive, if not an actual easing of policy.
description: Risk that tight financial conditions could undermine the expansion

quotation: The January and February jobs reports have been good, but still, year-over-year nonfarm payroll growth was 2.4 percent in January 2015 and has slowed to 1.6 percent today.
description: Job growth has slowed significantly from 2015 levels despite recent good reports

quotation: While there are few who will state conclusively that the Japanese economy is entering a deflationary spiral, there are many who express the concern that this could occur--particularly when they contemplate the condition of the Japanese banks
description: Japanese economy shows persistent weakness with deflationary concerns

quotation: Not to let that automatic stabilizer work would risk a self-reinforcing cumulative decline in activity because we don't know what is happening, as we didn't on the up side, to people's willingness to pay rates of interest for the use of money.
description: Warning about severe risks of preventing automatic monetary stabilizers from working

quotation: For 2(a): I would support using the stance of monetary policy to pursue financial stability goals in the circumstance in which the problem of financial instability is reaching macroeconomic proportions and cannot be addressed with other tools.
description: Monetary policy should be used for financial stability when problems reach macroeconomic proportions

quotation: I would agree with the notion that has been expressed by a number of people that we're probably stuck in the same old ditch for a while, rocking back and forth trying to gain the momentum to escape the gravitational pull of this deleveraging phenomenon.
description: Economy stuck in sluggish growth pattern due to deleveraging forces

quotation: Even with minimal reaction in the mortgage market, the Board staff estimates that the lending–borrowing channel accounts for only about one-third of the projected effect on the economy, with two-thirds coming through stock market and exchange rate effects. So some benefits would be realized even given the weak mortgage market.
description: Belief about policy transmission mechanisms and projected economic benefits

quotation: But it's obviously essential to the growth of every industry; and there's enormous leverage when credit gets tight, as we all know.
description: Credit is essential for economic growth and has enormous leverage when tight, with current conditions showing credit tightening

quotation: Having said all of that, the most recent CPI and PPI numbers and some of the commodity price increases are clearly disturbing.
description: Recent CPI, PPI, and commodity price increases are disturbing

quotation: I think the recession is spreading more and more into the loan books of these banks globally, and that's undermining confidence, despite government efforts everywhere to try to shore up confidence.
description: Recession is spreading into bank loan books, undermining confidence

quotation: And it's hard to find where monetary policy is biting very much. We see a little in real estate, and a few banks talk about their consumer credit [lending] at a fixed [interest] rate so they're beginning to slow down. But by and large it's hard to find very much bite any place.
description: Monetary policy is having limited impact on economic activity

quotation: The market is torn between two quite plausible scenarios. In one, we just grow below potential for a given period of time as credit conditions adjust to this new equilibrium; in the other, we have a deep and protracted recession driven as much by financial headwinds as by other fundamentals.
description: Two plausible scenarios: growth below potential during adjustment vs deep recession from financial headwinds

quotation: Similarly, in commercial real estate, the rise in CMBS spreads is not hampering activity, but merely prompting developers to switch to bank loans as a source of funding.
description: Commercial real estate credit markets remain functional despite rising CMBS spreads, with developers easily substituting bank loans

quotation: Overall, we think the risks are about evenly balanced between the economy growing too fast or starting to slow too much, although we don't see any signs really of cumulative softness.
description: Growth risks are balanced with no signs of cumulative softness

quotation: The dark scenario is the risk that the reduction in credit to the household sector amplifies the decline in housing demand, which leads to a greater adjustment in prices, with a risk of a more- pronounced, prolonged decline in growth and spending.
description: Risk scenario where reduced household credit amplifies housing decline and broader economic weakness

quotation: Unlike the financial situation in most previous economic contractions, it's hard to argue that financial system weakness and reduced credit availability have contributed or likely will contribute significantly to the decline in economic activity.
description: Financial system weakness and reduced credit availability have not contributed significantly to the current economic decline, unlike previous contractions

quotation: To quote one of my directors, "The crunch on Wall Street has not hit Main Street."
description: Wall Street financial stress has not impacted Main Street credit conditions

quotation: So I wonder whether governments are properly gauging their true medium-term costs of funding; and if complacency is, in fact, finding its way into financial markets, we cannot discount the prospect of some of these nonlinear outcomes in the financial markets, which would certainly do great harm to the economy.
description: Warning about potential nonlinear negative outcomes from financial market complacency

quotation: And in the event of a sharp drop in housing prices, the odds of a spillover to financial institutions seem limited.
description: Limited spillover risk from housing price declines to financial institutions

quotation: In contrast—and contrary to the Greenbook and the views of some—I think that energy and housing perhaps now more than credit problems are holding back economic growth.
description: Credit problems are less important than energy and housing issues in constraining economic growth

quotation: other factors may have reduced the sensitivity of spending to interest rates. One would hope that the excess capacity in nonresidential structures would sharply limit the usual response of this sector to declining interest rates
description: Excess capacity and balance sheet concerns are limiting the normal spending response to lower interest rates

quotation: With regard to the two scenarios I discussed this morning, in my opinion, the U.S. economy is entangled in a liquidity trap with amplification from a large Reinhart–Rogoff financial crisis. We could be staring at a lost decade
description: Economy in liquidity trap risks lost decade scenario

quotation: With these policy assumptions, my SEP projections have growth accelerating to above potential in 2014 and 2015. This forecast is also premised on many normal recovery factors, including pent-up demand and the waning of deleveraging effects.
description: Growth projected to accelerate above potential in 2014-2015 under continued accommodative policy

quotation: Because my fear is, as we're fighting this battle, we're increasingly creating what I'd call a vice that is gripping us—which is debt building up, building up, building up, building up. And it will continue to build up as we fight between unemployment and inflation to the point where I think that debt buildup itself will become enough of an excess that we become—I don't know what the word is—slowdown intolerant, or much more slowdown intolerant.
description: Debt buildup creates a "vice" that makes the economy less tolerant of slowdowns

quotation: One other issue that I think is worth flagging is the Iran sanctions and the threats of Iran to blockade the Strait of Hormuz potentially in response to those sanctions. Now, even if nothing dire actually occurs—things go a benign way rather than a bad way—the consequence could still be a persistent risk premium embedded in oil prices, and that could actually constrain real disposable income growth.
description: Iran sanctions could create persistent oil price risk premium that constrains real disposable income growth through inflation

quotation: If the inflection in the rate of growth at this late stage in the business cycle is in fact real--and it certainly appears less and less to be statistical noise as it continues quarter by quarter--then the issue essentially is why it is happening at a time when the unemployment rate is so low, when employers are of necessity drawing in marginal workers, even if we want to argue that they are not doing so extensively.
description: Current unemployment rate is very low and employers are drawing in marginal workers

quotation: The only real danger to this economic outlook, as I see it right now, is the financial structure. And that, as I think the Vice Chairman said, has a low probability of inducing a downturn. But if the financial system were to be ruptured, it would not be terribly difficult to bring the economy down very quickly.
description: Financial system fragility poses the main risk to economic growth, though with low probability

quotation: Long-term inflation expectations have been very stable in this whole period and indeed have dropped to historical lows in both the Michigan and Philadelphia surveys.
description: Long-term inflation expectations are stable and at historical lows

quotation: With regard to the credit channel, the hit to the nonfinancial sector has intensified a good bit. We clearly are sailing in uncharted waters when it comes to quantifying these effects.
description: Intensified credit channel impact on nonfinancial sector with unprecedented effects

quotation: At our last FOMC meeting, I worried about a slowdown in growth and a pickup in inflation. I hypothesized and hoped that both would prove transitory. On the whole, I consider recent data reassuring that the soft patch in the spring was just that—maybe not even that—and not a precursor of a more entrenched slowdown.
description: Recent growth slowdown in spring was transitory, not a precursor to more entrenched slowdown

quotation: The commercial real estate sector is still deteriorating and poses a threat to recovery in its potential drag on the credit system.
description: Commercial real estate deterioration poses threat to recovery through drag on credit system

quotation: Alternative A, or some lesser easing of policy, would seem to connote a judgment that effective restraint on the economy, signalled in part through the aggregates and the shrinkage of depository intermediation, was creating too big a risk of an unacceptable slowing of output or even a recession. An easing now could be viewed as a form of insurance, reducing the odds on recession if the credit situation is worse than now seems apparent.
description: Policy easing would serve as insurance against unacceptable output slowing or recession

quotation: I must confess that [a deficit of] $160 billion blows my mind as does the [potential for] crowding out. But I think we have to recognize that it's a quite different kind of deficit in the sense that previously we had the tax rebate or whatever that was called and then [the financial system] had to turn around and lend to corporations to supply the goods to take care of the [unintelligible], so there really was a double whammy in the finance market.
description: Current deficit has structurally different impact on financial markets compared to previous deficits due to changes in fiscal policy design

quotation: The bankers report some slowing in C&I loans but not as a forerunner of a recession.
description: Current slowing in C&I loans is part of desired economic adjustment, not a recession signal

quotation: And even if it is not justified, the deterioration in financial conditions may itself contaminate real activity by holding back household consumption or business hiring and investment.
description: Deteriorating financial conditions could negatively impact business hiring and investment

quotation: At this time, there are significant downside risks to the economy and financial markets, as the collateral damage from the housing problems works through the economy and financial institutions.
description: Significant downside risks to economy from housing market spillovers

quotation: We will have had a year of 4 percent real GDP growth; the economy would be growing beyond potential. The output gap is eliminated at that point, and the unemployment rate is at 5.3 percent, which is your estimate of the NAIRU.
description: Forecast that unemployment rate will reach 5.3 percent by end of 2003, which equals the estimated NAIRU

quotation: Some of the monoline subprime originators would be unable to exist if there weren't a securitized demand for those assets.
description: Many subprime originators are structurally dependent on securitization markets and would fail without them

quotation: Some expressed the view that more-significant write-downs and financial stress lie ahead, as house prices continue to fall and the slowing economy weakens credit quality, and that the full impact of tighter credit has not yet been felt in the nonfinancial economy.
description: More significant credit losses and financial stress lie ahead with continued real economy effects

quotation: I think we need substantial further accommodation after today's meeting. I see the timing and the size of those actions for the most part being shaped by the large recessionary forces in train and the enormous financial headwinds.
description: Financial headwinds require substantial further accommodation

quotation: My business contacts do not see the current price and availability of credit as impediments to capital spending. Perhaps they don't appreciate the various other channels through which lower interest rates might help the economy, such as through the influence on exchange rates and balance sheets.
description: Credit availability and pricing are not currently impediments to business investment, though monetary policy may still work through other transmission channels

quotation: Europe is more bank-dependent than the United States, and we may be underestimating the likely credit crunch that will accompany their recession, as well as the political turmoil generated by what is likely to be staggering unemployment rates in much of southern Europe.
description: Europe faces a likely credit crunch due to its bank-dependence, which could have spillover effects

quotation: And, three, will this lead to credit rating downgrades? In other words, if this process goes on long enough, will the credit rating agencies feel some need to respond to the deterioration in the stock prices and the widening credit default swap spreads by cutting the credit ratings, which then could feed back through in terms of the funding, which would be pretty dangerous?
description: Credit market deterioration could trigger dangerous feedback loops through rating downgrades and funding problems

quotation: I think the conditions that made the first two LSAP programs successful—a lack of liquidity in MBS markets in the case of LSAP1 and elevated concerns about outright deflation in the case of LSAP2—are not present in the current environment. This time around, it seems to me that we face a more conventional problem of inadequate demand, and I am not convinced that lowering general market rates will stimulate much credit expansion and spending.
description: Current conditions make monetary policy transmission through credit markets less effective than in previous LSAP programs

quotation: Higher bond yields likely reflect expectations of strong economic growth as well as the firming of inflation expectations, and they are unlikely to provide much of a drag on economic activity.
description: Strong economic growth expectations reflected in bond yields won't constrain economic activity

quotation: From the bankers' side, we have significant indications of more interest in capital spending by business firms. Unfortunately for the bankers, most of it will be financed internally or outside the banking system.
description: Business capital spending will be financed internally or outside the banking system rather than through bank loans

quotation: Lower farm incomes will, I believe, lead to some rise in farm loan problems this year. However, most banks had strong portfolios coming into the year and should be able to absorb likely increases in delinquencies.
description: Farm loan problems are expected to rise due to lower farm incomes, but banks should be able to absorb the increases

quotation: I am thinking primarily in terms of the financial strains that the system will be under. I think we've all been amazed at the willingness of consumers and businessmen to take on loans at extremely high rates. And it seems to me the counterpart of this is that we may go into a recession [with] an awful lot of strains that are likely to lead to a deeper recession.
description: Financial strains from high borrowing rates could cause a deeper recession

quotation: The outlook does not seem to have changed significantly from the last time we were here when there appeared to be some form of financial ceiling on the economy basically represented by the balance sheet pressures and essentially reflected in the fact that every time the economy seems to pick up, long-term interest rates seem to go up.
description: Economy faces a financial ceiling where growth pickup triggers higher long-term rates

quotation: True, there seem to be a few signs at the national level of slowing in interest-sensitive sectors; but we have seen these signs before and they've simply been pauses.
description: Previous signs of slowing in interest-sensitive sectors have proven to be temporary pauses rather than sustained cooling

quotation: Working out the thrift situation and recapitalizing these institutions may have a pronounced effect on the patterns of financial flows, but is much less likely to affect the overall level of interest rates or economic activity.
description: Thrift situation resolution unlikely to significantly affect overall economic activity

quotation: There could be more plant and equipment, and there could be more inflation. All that would add to the nominal GNP, and it would also add to the corporate, business financing need of the year as it went on.
description: Forecast of potential for more inflation with consequences for corporate financing needs

quotation: I think business and consumer confidence are likely to get worse and the stresses and the cracks in the financial system are likely to weigh more substantially on aggregate demand during the coming months than is built into the forecast.
description: Financial system stresses will weigh more heavily on aggregate demand than expected

quotation: And more powerful than market concentration is the increase in price transparency. This is having a significant effect on sellers' ability to raise prices even when they face cost pressures... and the reduced bargaining power of labor, which was noted in the box.
description: Labor has reduced bargaining power, limiting wage pressures despite tight markets

quotation: Wage developments and other labor market data are consistent with an economy that is near full employment. The Conference Board survey released this morning shows that the gap between the percentage of consumers who view jobs as plentiful and those who see jobs as scarce is at a 16-year high
description: Labor market indicators consistent with near full employment

quotation: Although we do not have housing starts and permits for August, the outlook for the second half of 2007 is likely to deteriorate further than forecasters had predicted before the liquidity issues.
description: Economic outlook for second half 2007 likely to deteriorate more than previously forecast due to liquidity issues

quotation: Finally, the danger of provoking a severe downturn seems to me to be protected against--not guaranteed against, obviously--both by the endogenous workings of the economy, such as the inventory turnaround, financial endogenous factors such as the possible drop in interest rates if the economy stays very weak, and the exogenous factors of the tax cut and social security increase.
description: Multiple factors protect against severe economic downturn

quotation: most of which is being held by quite nonleveraged institutions. And so I actually don't think, as we have looked at this, that we have seen it as a financial stability risk, as conventionally understood, so much as, instead, a potential macroprudential risk because of what would happen to the real economy if there were an awful lot of bankruptcies, which then carried through into affecting the end investors.
description: Potential bankruptcies could have significant negative consequences for the real economy

quotation: I think the fragility of the world debt situation is such that probing downward makes sense. I think that is the major risk to our recovery on a three-year basis; it's a major risk to the world's recovery; and it's a major risk to the financial institutions, particularly the commercial banking institutions in this country in terms of write-offs and their possible contraction of credit in a different sense than we use that term. Therefore, I would be very cautious in probing upward and quite willing to probe down.
description: World debt fragility poses risks to financial institutions that could lead to credit contraction, warranting accommodative monetary policy

quotation: On the inflation side, I think the trend is continuing to be favorable; what I hear anecdotally is very much consistent with what Mike has suggested.
description: Inflation trends are continuing to be favorable based on anecdotal evidence

quotation: Now, normally you would expect to see a tightening of credit conditions affect the economy with some lag. It takes time for people to borrow money and to use the money they borrow to make expenditures. But compared with that prediction, we have instead seen a sudden stop—a remarkable and very rapid effect on economic activity.
description: Credit conditions are affecting the economy more rapidly than normal transmission mechanisms would predict

quotation: when I think about what people say about credit constraints, the idea of a consumer with given characteristics—FICO score, income, and everything—with GDP growth of plus 3 versus GDP growth of minus 5, the identical consumer is going to be riskier in the second situation
description: GDP growth conditions affect consumer riskiness and lending standards

quotation: We went through a period when recessions had "victim" sectors. Inflation would push up nominal interest rates, which would lead to disintermediation because of Regulation Q. The housing and auto sectors would get clobbered, and then we'd get a big snapback recovery. We don't have that occurring this time. So when we look at something like a diffusion index of employment, knowing the nature of what caused contractions in the past, are we looking at the same thing?
description: Employment recovery patterns have changed structurally compared to past recessions, with traditional interest-sensitive sector contractions and snapback recoveries no longer occurring

quotation: Standard econometric estimates would say that a 1 percent overshoot--1 percent as measured by the unemployment rate for an entire year--would add about 1/2 percent to the inflation rate.
description: Standard econometric estimates suggest 1% unemployment overshoot adds 0.5% to inflation rate

quotation: In the Eleventh District we've seen some modest weakening in the numbers and some deterioration in the tone of the anecdotal information. It's somewhat more negative, primarily surrounding uncertainty over the future.
description: Current cyclical weakening observed in Eleventh District growth indicators

quotation: The key to all of this, however, is whether the debt holders, when they lose money in the downturn—as they will because that's what happens in a downturn—will fail to lend more or whether they will fail altogether. If they fail to lend more, credit tightens and that weakens the economy further; if they fail altogether, then you have an unstable financial system.
description: Framework for understanding how credit losses transmit through the financial system to the broader economy

quotation: The credit markets have been deteriorating. That's led to a sharp weakening of the economy's prospects. This is reflected in the very large change in the Greenbook forecast, with which I do strongly concur, so I don't think that it was out of line to put those in. Of course, that weakening has been feeding back to deteriorating financial conditions
description: Credit market deterioration leading to economic weakening through adverse feedback loops

quotation: Manufacturing activity was flat for the second month in a row in August, after improving most of the year until then.
description: Manufacturing activity has flattened after earlier improvement

quotation: Liquidity at the present time exists in the sense of plenty of funds around--could very well be the result of slack business rather than a cause of better business. That is always a possibility. So the fact that there are seemingly idle funds around does not suggest to me necessarily that these funds are going to go to work.
description: Current liquidity abundance may be a result of slack business conditions rather than a driver of better business, questioning its effectiveness

quotation: As has already been discussed, an important area of risk to the forecast involves developments in credit markets. The survey evidence on availability constraints is spotty and a bit dated. Those results, from banks and small businesses, suggested some tightening of standards through August and perhaps beyond.
description: Survey evidence suggests credit standards have tightened through August and potentially beyond, representing an important risk to the economic forecast

quotation: I'm not sure that it isn't going to be relatively mild. We don't have the credit control program we had in force that contributed to the sharp downturn both in the economy and in the money supply last year.
description: Expectation that economic downturn will be relatively mild compared to previous experience

quotation: Following such a strategy also enables us to do what we can to support an improved employment picture.
description: Policy preference to support improved employment picture

quotation: So, I think we're currently facing a stalled out economy, which is projected to dip into negative territory. What concerns me on top of that is the increasingly tight credit market conditions. With the lags in the process, I think we do have a risk of turning a mild downturn into a fairly ugly situation.
description: Tight credit conditions risk turning mild downturn into severe recession

quotation: There are a lot of positive signs on the durability or sustainability issue. There's ample evidence that we've made progress on this 3-year depressant of the deleveraging process with the improvement in corporate balance sheets.
description: Positive signs for recovery durability including improved corporate balance sheets and consumer deleveraging progress

quotation: In view of the millions of jobs the economy has added since 2009, it would seem perverse to delay liftoff if August payrolls fell short of expectations by, say, 100,000.
description: Millions of jobs added since 2009 support rate increases despite potential monthly volatility

quotation: After all, the rapid reduction in subprime lending is exacerbating the decline in housing demand and thus home sales, contributing to the slower recovery of that sector.
description: Rapid reduction in subprime lending is exacerbating housing market decline

quotation: We did run a special survey of about 100 bankers in the areas of the District affected by the floods. I guess it's reassuring to report that they didn't have anything very startling to say in the sense that while crop losses in some cases are substantial, they are not expecting major spillover effects on economic activity.
description: Bankers in flood-affected areas do not expect major economic spillover effects from crop losses, indicating stable credit market conditions

quotation: In the 1930s, when the economy was doing very badly and banks were failing—I'm telling this to you, and you've described it to everyone—then the knock-on effect was that the banks weren't there anymore and important resources for evaluating credit were lost, and so it was more expensive and very difficult to do.
description: Financial disruption impairs credit intermediation capacity similar to Great Depression

quotation: I am not yet convinced, however, that recent financial market volatility and repricing of credit risk will have significant implications for the growth outlook. It is still reasonable at this point to think that the recent volatility will prove transitory, and the repricing of credit risk is, in that sense, desirable.
description: Recent financial market volatility and credit risk repricing will be transitory and the repricing is desirable

quotation: We will not be able to judge for some time what the fallout of all these events may be, but it is certainly highly likely that they will act to some degree to damp the pace of the expansion. I can readily envision the possibility that the impact, once all of these dominoes have fallen, would be at or perhaps beyond the severe end of the range that we presently envision.
description: Financial market turbulence will likely dampen economic expansion, potentially severely

quotation: That will no doubt provide some support for business fixed investment; it will encourage that to come along. When the environment improves and becomes more buoyant, we will start to see rates on longer maturity instruments go in the other direction. That will be part of a self- stabilizing or self-equilibrating process as well.
description: Credit markets have self-equilibrating mechanisms that will support business investment and automatically adjust rates as conditions improve

quotation: Another time when the Phillips curve was supposedly at death's door was back in the late 1990s, when rapid productivity growth drove both inflation and unemployment down
description: Historical example of productivity growth driving down both inflation and unemployment

quotation: I do not know just what caused what, but with household debt burdens--if one includes leasing payments as Governor Lindsey likes to do--approaching all time highs and with bankruptcies surging and consumer credit charge-offs running well above expectations, it is not very surprising that lenders would tighten standards.
description: High household debt burdens, surging bankruptcies, and elevated charge-offs are causing lenders to tighten credit standards

quotation: One way to get it, and there's some evidence for this, is that when the FOMC lowers short-term rates—and you can see this in the data—banks extend their maturities. They're buying, and you can see the dealers having to sell to them. It looks like a move in term premiums rather than a move in expectations, and it looks like a move in term premiums that kind of reverts over 6 to 12 months.
description: Banks extend maturities and buy longer-term securities when the Fed lowers short-term rates

quotation: There are some signs out there that are very worrisome: this whole real estate fungus that is spreading across the country, which is a [unintelligible] of price resistance; the slowness of the markets; and increasing pressures on prices. It's not going to be helped at all by the cranking up of the activities of the RTC. And I think that's now being reflected in the serious concern that the markets are showing for the whole banking sector.
description: Real estate market problems and banking sector stress are creating serious concerns in credit markets

quotation: However, a growing risk to my outlook is that the short-term weakness that I have now built into my outlook extends further out into the forecast period. I worry that my outlook doesn't fully capture all of the many ways in which financial forces at work in the economy are actually going to restrain spending.
description: Risk that short-term weakness extends further due to financial forces restraining spending

quotation: What accounts for the inability of this recovery to make significant headway in reducing the significant slack in the economy? First, I think we have underestimated the financial headwinds generated by the financial crisis.
description: Financial headwinds from the crisis explain the slow recovery

quotation: some of the German authorities have put restructuring on the table after keeping that very much off the table for many months. This is not a timely development, because it obviously sets in place very bad dynamics leading to much higher interest rates in the periphery, lower prices, and that, of course, just reinforces the likelihood that the restructuring will have to take place
description: European sovereign debt restructuring discussions are creating adverse credit market dynamics

quotation: Business borrowing continues sluggish, but, perhaps more because internal funds and equity are in ample supply to support capi- tal spending than out of reluctance to borrow or constraints on cre- dit availability.
description: Business borrowing remains sluggish but this reflects ample internal funds rather than credit constraints

quotation: So one thing that this does is simply to cut into profitability and the ability to earn your way out of the challenges. An easy way to do it— of just allowing the machine to go forward—is going to produce less than it otherwise would.
description: High funding costs reduce bank profitability and ability to work through credit problems

quotation: We can no longer count on the "melting-up" in these markets to do the hard work of helping repair balance sheets of financial institutions and households.
description: Credit markets can no longer be relied upon to repair balance sheets

quotation: At any rate, these considerations increase the difficulty of assessing at this point just how much easing will be appropriate and provide a rationale for a gradual, incremental strategy of easing.
description: Uncertainty about spending strength and appropriate degree of easing supports gradual policy approach

quotation: I'm also in agreement generally that inflation is under control by almost any measure.
description: Inflation is currently under control by almost any measure

quotation: I would point out that the same pessimism about future conditions that drives the reserving also drives the underwriting conditions for future loans, and that is why they are continuing to tighten.
description: Pessimism about future economic conditions drives both loan loss reserving and tightening of underwriting standards

quotation: Given the lags in the process, if we wait much longer, we run the risk of this credit situation producing some real damage six months from now and turning a mild downturn into something that could be more severe.
description: Waiting too long risks credit problems causing severe economic damage

quotation: The contraction of credit availability that is confirmed by both surveys and anecdotal evidence could deepen as financial institutions face tight liquidity and difficulty recapitalizing. A protracted credit crunch would likely operate as a substantial drag on the economy.
description: Credit crunch could operate as substantial drag on economic growth

quotation: It also seems likely that a slowdown in credit-driven business investment will lead to slower growth in job incomes and wealth-driven consumption. Thus far this year consumption has surprised us on the upside, driven by tight labor markets and by high equity values. It seems, though, that both of these factors have begun to unravel or will shortly do so. Equity markets already have done so. Labor markets will adjust gradually over time.
description: Labor markets are expected to weaken gradually as economic conditions adjust, with tight labor markets currently supporting consumption but expected to unravel

quotation: Secondly, we think the contribution of agricultural exports might be somewhat stronger. There has been an announcement that Red China is coming into our market for small grain, wheat principally. And if the attitude of that nation were such as to buy rather significant amounts in our markets, it could make a substantial difference in our trade balance.
description: Agricultural exports will be stronger than expected due to Chinese grain purchases, potentially making substantial difference in trade balance

quotation: But, at least in my judgment, what has occurred is probably a normal function of the financial intermediary in requiring some of these excesses to be turned in order to move into the next crop season. We see a tight situation but not one in which, absent a severe drought, there are no crops growing of any substantial amounts for 1977, that there is any crisis situation in this part of world.
description: Current tight credit situation is a normal function of financial intermediaries and manageable, not a crisis

quotation: After almost six years of highly-accommodative policy, the risks are out there and continue to build. To be specific, the risk in the near term, to me, is not that of a meltdown at the core of the system, which is much stronger and better protected than before the crisis, but rather that of a sharp correction amplified by the liquidity mismatch in the markets that would damage or halt the progress of what is still a weak economy.
description: Financial risks are building after six years of accommodative policy, with potential for sharp corrections amplified by liquidity mismatches

quotation: A sharp drop in house prices would likely crimp consumer spending over time through wealth and collateral effects.
description: Sharp house price declines would reduce consumer spending through wealth and collateral effects

quotation: New England continues to grow modestly, though recent data suggest that some caution is warranted. District employment growth remains slower than that of the nation.
description: Assessment of modest regional growth with caution warranted

quotation: Housing and retail sales have continued to perform reasonably well despite higher mortgage interest rates and inclement weather.
description: Housing and retail sales have remained resilient despite higher mortgage interest rates

quotation: Although I don't see inflation as much of a risk in the near term, my inflation outlook is less sanguine than the Tealbook's is for some time. I believe there are risks of higher inflation in the medium term.
description: Near-term inflation risks are low but medium-term inflation risks are elevated

quotation: I do not see credit being restricted—quite the opposite.
description: Credit is currently abundant, not restricted

quotation: In particular, the still-parlous state of household balance sheets could restrain consumption more than is incorporated in the Greenbook. In the past, I have highlighted the potential drag on consumer spending that we may see if households, to rebuild wealth and reduce leverage, boost their saving beyond the rather modest rebound incorporated in the Greenbook forecast.
description: Household balance sheet repair could significantly restrain consumption and economic growth

quotation: The lower path is just much tougher. We're still close to the natural rate. We're still eliminating slack, but at a much slower pace, and I think that, more important, the economy is more vulnerable to an unwanted tightening in financial conditions and probably in a nonlinear way. I would still want to lift off, just a little bit later.
description: Under a slower growth scenario, would prefer later policy liftoff due to increased vulnerability

quotation: It is less likely to be accompanied by an inde- pendent credit rationing or availability effect, such as those that formerly added to the restraint imposed by higher interest rates in disintermediation episodes prior to deposit rate decontrol.
description: Current financial market conditions are less likely to produce independent credit rationing effects compared to past disintermediation episodes

quotation: While banks now receive less direct funding from prime money market funds, banks are increasingly the recipients of funds coming indirectly from government money market funds through the Federal Home Loan Banks. Should real estate values sink and confidence about the implicit government backing of the Federal Home Loan Banks drop, investors might run from funds with large Federal Home Loan Bank exposures, especially if those Federal Home Loan Banks are weakly capitalized.
description: Current credit market arrangements create potential for financial instability if real estate values decline and confidence in Federal Home Loan Bank backing drops

quotation: You are all sounding like the final quarter before the downturn, quite frankly.
description: Economy appears to be in final quarter before downturn begins

quotation: Again, slowing profit growth will, we think, tend to slow business investment. As we discussed yesterday afternoon, it will negatively affect the credit cycle—which is a nice way of saying that credit spreads are going to widen, which will further tighten financial conditions and may ultimately begin to affect employment trends.
description: Tightening financial conditions from slowing profit growth may ultimately affect employment trends

quotation: The risk is that the balance sheet overhangs and elevated asset values leave the economy more susceptible to sharp corrections that could produce considerable economic instability.
description: Balance sheet overhangs and elevated asset values increase susceptibility to sharp economic corrections

quotation: I combine this with the fact that corporate debt is at relatively high levels by historical standards, and corporate activism—shareholder activism—is at historically high levels, which means corporate executives are going to take action much more quickly than in the past in the face of earnings deterioration.
description: Corporate executives will respond more quickly to earnings deterioration due to high debt levels and shareholder activism

quotation: While there has not been much change in the level of risk since the previous report, business debt remains a concern, and standards and terms have continued to deteriorate. And the losses on these loans could amplify an economic downturn.
description: Business debt remains a concern with deteriorating standards and terms that could amplify economic downturns

quotation: I've noticed that the triple-B tranche of debt securities has been growing really rapidly relative to the other investment grades. Are we thinking at all about the risk of next recession? A lot of those triple-Bs become high yield, The triple-B market now is much bigger than the high-yield market, and those cliff effects could actually lead to quite a bit of pressure on firms, because a lot of people can't invest in high yields.
description: Concern about rapid growth in triple-B debt securities creating financial stability risks during economic downturns

quotation: Since our decision to begin normalizing interest rates in December, the news from the labor and output markets has continued to arrive in a familiar pattern: a very strong labor market with disappointing real spending.
description: Current output growth is disappointing despite strong labor market conditions

quotation: There has been a pickup in demand for temporary industrial workers, according to my contacts at Manpower. In addition, Manpower's latest survey results, which won't be released publicly until next Monday, show hiring plans for the fourth quarter to be very strong again. What is not clear, though, is whether all these jobs will be filled.
description: Strong hiring demand but uncertainty about filling positions due to tight labor markets

quotation: Alternatively, however, weak money and credit may primarily reflect balance sheet restructuring with minimal implications for aggregate demand, and the declines in interest rates may simply reflect market anticipation and then digestion of the policy easing combined with the belated recognition by bond holders that inflation is not likely to accelerate appreciably in the next few years.
description: Alternative explanation that weak credit reflects healthy balance sheet restructuring rather than economic weakness

quotation: For example, our model may not fully incorporate the levels of debt held by both businesses and consumers and the implied fixed nominal payments associated with those commitments. Further shocks that hinder cash flows could generate more dislocations and thereby slow the progress to profitability.
description: High debt levels among businesses and consumers create structural vulnerabilities with fixed payment obligations that models may not adequately capture, and further economic shocks could worsen debt-related dislocations

quotation: And I mention it because we've got this issue of daily liquidity being offered by mutual funds. They think that's going to be stressed again in this scenario. You're going to have a mismatch, and it's going to be apparent. You're going to have a widening of spreads. It's going to tighten conditions broadly, because these funds will sell what's liquid, and they won't be able to sell others.
description: Mutual fund liquidity mismatches will amplify credit market stress through forced selling

quotation: The message we heard is that the new employee is not so easy to find and that many of the unemployed lacked the skills and the attitude to fill these redefined jobs.
description: Skills and attitude mismatch between unemployed workers and job requirements

quotation: As I mentioned yesterday, low rates are energizing a positive feedback loop in residential and commercial real estate, which is providing critical impetus for a faster recovery.
description: Low rates are creating positive feedback loops in real estate credit markets that provide critical support for economic recovery

quotation: And, even if the staff's baseline is the best modal forecast, the Committee might perceive some odds--albeit small--of an even worse market disruption that could spread further and feed back more forcefully on the U.S. economy and financial markets.
description: Risk of worse market disruption feeding back on US economy

quotation: Real GDP growth for the second quarter came in somewhat weaker than many expected, although I will note that as recently as April many people were expecting negative growth in the second quarter and it is now almost 2 percent. But I think that the strength is a remarkable testament to the ability of this economy to weather shocks from financial market disruptions, a severe housing correction, and surges in energy and commodity prices.
description: Second quarter GDP growth demonstrated economic resilience despite challenges

quotation: Moreover, because markets are placing some weight on a 75 basis point move, a further 50 basis point reduction in the funds rate at this meeting is unlikely to boost the stock market, depreciate the dollar, or lower bond yields. With limited follow-through in financial markets from policy easing, as Dave has explained, economic growth remains below the growth of potential in the staff forecast and the unemployment rate rises rapidly.
description: Limited financial market transmission of monetary policy easing reduces its effectiveness

quotation: Mr. Chairman, I am a little concerned about these inflationary expectations in the economy, but like some others here, I don't see it being translated at the moment into anything that is terribly worrisome in real numbers.
description: Inflationary expectations not translating to concerning real outcomes

quotation: My sense is that, while we may see some marginal slowing in business investment, the effects are likely to be small because I don't think the marginal cost of funding for most businesses has gone up much and we aren't hearing reports of wholesale tightening of lending standards in the corporate sector.
description: Business investment effects from financial turmoil expected to be limited due to stable funding costs and lending standards

quotation: Amid the gloom of the credit crunch, I do see a possible silver lining in that it may amplify the effects of the fiscal stimulus package, and this is part of the reason that my forecasted downturn is a little milder than the Greenbook's.
description: Speaker believes fiscal stimulus may amplify and make the economic downturn milder than otherwise expected

quotation: As you described the economy, there were some fundamentals in terms of real estate and some adjustments in leverages and so forth that are going to be constraining. If we ease now, what in your judgment is the risk of pushing inflation [up] and compromising our ability to bring it down in the future, given these fundamental adjustments that probably should continue regardless?
description: Leverage adjustments in credit markets are currently constraining the economy, and these adjustments should be allowed to continue rather than being offset by monetary easing

quotation: Although in my view the reassessment of risk in the subprime mortgage market suggests that this market is working as it should, the overall weakening in credit conditions in the mortgage market increases uncertainty as to whether the housing correction will be contained or whether it will spill over into other sectors of the economy.
description: Weakening mortgage credit conditions create uncertainty about economic spillover effects, though subprime risk reassessment represents healthy market functioning

quotation: That in turn further tightened financial conditions, leading to more markdown of growth prospects.
description: Tighter financial conditions have led to markdown of growth prospects

quotation: I am a little disappointed that this move in these asset prices hasn't done more to help the real economy get back on its front foot. I'm a little disappointed that it hasn't helped durable final demand.
description: Disappointment that asset price increases haven't sufficiently helped real economy and durable demand

quotation: When I read that sales of light trucks are now starting to show some weakness, that gave me some concern because they have been extremely strong. We had some plant closings announced in the area of heavy trucks... And I personally believe we're going to see some more of that looking ahead.
description: Truck sales showing weakness across light and heavy truck segments

quotation: However, the rise in asset prices and residential investment and the leverage caused by this long period of very expansionary monetary policy may lead to a process of adjustment in asset prices that could be more sustained and more damaging in terms of confidence and of demand than we expect. This risk is greater if we end up allowing more inflation than our forecast anticipates, for the required monetary policy response could induce an even sharper adjustment in risk premiums and asset prices.
description: Expansionary monetary policy created leverage and asset price risks that could lead to damaging adjustments if inflation is allowed to rise

quotation: Conversations with a variety of market participants in Boston indicate that such sales are not anticipated and would be viewed as a signal that we wanted mortgage rates much higher, with the potential to dramatically slow a housing sector just beginning to recover.
description: MBS sales would signal tighter mortgage policy and harm housing recovery

quotation: The forecast, as a result, overall depends on the ability of nonfinancial corporations to hire and invest despite this macroeconomic uncertainty. I have some confidence that the Fortune 500 will be willing to continue to push along this path of moderate growth; but small companies, particularly those that are really the source of job creation, may be more negatively affected while the credit channel is impaired, and this is happening at a critical time.
description: Small companies, which are the primary source of job creation, are more vulnerable to credit channel impairment than large corporations

quotation: As a consequence, I think those people who are employed and are consuming probably have a greater degree of confidence than we are giving them credit for having, despite the increasing levels of debt. So I would say net on that score that we will probably see a continued expansion.
description: Forecast of continued economic expansion driven by consumer confidence

quotation: The second factor that has been mentioned a couple of times is the possibility that shocks--and I wouldn't call them just financial shocks, Henry, but shocks that originate in the financial sector which may be affecting primarily nonfinancial firms--may be coming along that will cause great consternation around the nation and make the attitudes still worse.
description: Potential financial sector shocks could worsen economic attitudes and performance

quotation: But I don't think we're at the point yet where we can say that confidently, not because they haven't deleveraged sufficiently or bought enough liquidity—though there's a bit of that still left—but because there's so much uncertainty left still about the scale of pressure on balance sheets, what that might do to the losses, what that might do to asset prices going forward or to behavior.
description: Financial firms are not yet ready to function without Fed support due to continued uncertainty about balance sheet pressures and losses

quotation: I think inflation is too high, and I see increasing evidence that inflationary pressures are building, especially in labor markets.
description: Inflationary pressures are building, particularly in labor markets

quotation: While our forecast assumes a gradual decline in real estate prices, it does not have a substantial feedback between rising unemployment rates causing further downward pressure on real estate prices and the health of financial institutions.
description: Rising unemployment could create negative feedback loops with real estate prices and financial institution health
